hypotheses: Lower per capita income is associated with reduced social distancing among U.S. counties.
Greater Republican (Trump) political orientation is associated with reduced social distancing among U.S. counties.
claim.hypotheses_location: Introduction: final sentence ('This study examines the socioeconomic and political determinants of engagement in social distancing among U.S. counties.')
claim.statement: Using 15–17 million anonymized cell phone records, we find that lower per capita income and greater Republican orientation were associated with significantly reduced social distancing among U.S. counties.

data.source: Mobility data from Unacast (anonymized cell phone records); county sociodemographic and labor market data from the American Community Survey (ACS, 5-year averages 2014–2018); 2016 county-level vote share data from MIT Election Data and Science Lab; rurality from the 2010 Census.
data.wave_or_subset: Social distancing measured for March 19–28, 2020 relative to matched days of a pre-COVID-19 reference week; ACS 5-year averages 2014–2018 used for covariates.
data.sample_size: 3,037 counties; mobility estimates based on 15–17 million anonymized cell phone users per day.
data.access_details: Unacast provided their social distancing dataset for research use (acknowledged in paper). ACS and MIT Election Data and Science Lab are named as sources. No direct download links or access instructions provided in the paper.
data.notes: Social distancing operationalized as percentage-point change in average distance traveled relative to a matched pre-COVID reference week. The median county experienced a decrease in average mobility of 27.3 percentage points during March 19–28. Authors note potential measurement error because data do not sample all cell-phone users and exclude non-users; ecological and omitted-variable bias possible due to aggregate cross-sectional data.

method.description: Cross-sectional analysis of county-level change in average mobility (proxy for social distancing) for March 19–28, 2020 using anonymized cell phone data. Main exposures were county per capita income and 2016 Trump vote share, with adjustment for county sociodemographic and labor market covariates and state fixed effects. Associations estimated using ordinary least squares regression.
steps: Obtain county-level mobility data from Unacast (average distance traveled per person) for March 19–28, 2020 and matched pre-COVID-19 reference week.
Compute percentage-point change in average distance traveled for March 19–28 relative to matched pre-COVID-19 days (outcome).
Obtain county-level per capita income and sociodemographic/labor market covariates from the ACS (2014–2018 5-year estimates).
Obtain county-level 2016 Presidential vote share for Trump from MIT Election Data and Science Lab.
Merge datasets at the county level and include rurality from the 2010 Census.

Run bivariate analyses and multivariable cross-sectional ordinary least squares (OLS) regressions for percentage-point change in average mobility, adjusting for sociodemographic and labor market covariates and including state fixed effects.
Report coefficients, 95% confidence intervals, and p-values; produce figures showing bivariate associations.
method.models: Multivariable ordinary least squares (OLS) regression with state fixed effects; bivariate linear regressions (unadjusted) for figure fits.
method.outcome_variable: Percentage-point change in average county mobility (average distance traveled) for March 19–28, 2020 relative to matched pre-COVID-19 reference week. Negative values indicate a greater degree of social distancing (larger declines in mobility).
method.independent_variables: Primary exposures: county per capita income (income per capita) and 2016 county-level vote share for President Trump (share of Trump voters).
method.control_variables: Percentage male; percentage Black; percentage Hispanic; age distribution (percentage for each decade of life); percentage with college degree; employment shares in retail, transportation, and health/education/social services; percentage rural; state fixed effects.

results.summary: Bivariate analyses showed that lower per capita income and higher Trump vote share were associated with reduced social distancing. In multivariable OLS models adjusting for sociodemographic and labor market characteristics and state fixed effects (3,037 counties), an interquartile increase in per capita income was associated with greater social distancing (~1.4 percentage points), while an interquartile increase in Trump support was associated with reduced social distancing (~4.1 percentage points). Higher shares of racial minorities and residents without college degrees were also associated with less distancing. There were no significant associations by population share of gender or age.

numerical_results.unit: percentage points (per IQR increase in income)
numerical_results.effect_size: -1.36 (interpreted as a 1.36 percentage-point greater degree of social distancing given that negative values indicate more distancing)
numerical_results.direction: negative (higher income associated with greater reduction in mobility / more social distancing)

numerical_results.unit: percentage points (per IQR increase in Trump vote share)
numerical_results.direction: positive (higher Trump support associated with less reduction in mobility / less social distancing)

numerical_results.unit: percentage points (per percentage point increase in Black share)
numerical_results.direction: positive (higher Black share associated with less social distancing / smaller reductions in mobility)

numerical_results.unit: percentage points (per percentage point increase in Hispanic share)
numerical_results.direction: positive (higher Hispanic share associated with less social distancing)

numerical_results.unit: percentage points (per percentage point increase in share with college degree)
numerical_results.direction: negative (higher share with college degree associated with greater social distancing)

numerical_results.unit: percentage points (per percentage point increase in retail employment share)
numerical_results.direction: positive (higher retail employment associated with less social distancing)

numerical_results.unit: percentage points (per percentage point increase in transportation employment share)
numerical_results.direction: positive (higher transportation employment associated with less social distancing)

numerical_results.unit: percentage points (per percentage point increase in health/education/social services employment share)
numerical_results.direction: positive (higher employment in these sectors associated with less social distancing)
negative (large reduction in mobility indicating social distancing)

metadata.original_paper_title: Association of County-Level Socioeconomic and Political Characteristics with Engagement in Social Distancing for COVID-19
